metadata.title: Highly stable Ru nanoparticles anchored on NiFe layered double hydroxides as efficient water splitting electrocatalysts

Fig. 5 Highly stable Ru nanoparticles anchored on NiFe layered double hydroxides as efficient water splitting electrocatalysts Zhiwei Zhang Investigation Writing – original draft a Wenxia Chen Writing (QUT), Brisbane, QLD 4000, Australia ⁎ Corresponding authors. Developing efficient and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts is highly desirable for boosting the energy efficiency of water splitting. Herein, we propose an effective ruthenium nanoparticle anchoring approach to reconstruct NiFe LDH including the customized morphology and configuration of active species. The synthesized NiFe LDH-Ru shows an excellent HER and OER performance with low overpotentials of 52 and 217 mV at 10 mA cm−2, respectively, which exceeds most of the existing HER and OER catalysts. Moreover, the NiFe LDH-Ru catalyst also presents excellent long-term stability. This work provides a new approach for exploring efficient electrocatalysts for clean and renewable energy applications. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords NiFe LDH Ru nanoparticles HER OER Overall water splitting Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Electrochemical water splitting is one of the most promising strategies to produce clean and sustainable H2 [1–5]. Nevertheless, the electrochemical water oxidation (OER) restricts the overall reaction efficiency due to the inherent sluggish kinetics in the water electrolysis process [6–11]. Nowadays, many prospective transition metal-based materials, such as oxides [12], sulfides [13], phosphides [14], layered double hydroxides (LDH) [15], etc. have attracted strong research interest. The NiFe layered double hydroxides (NiFe LDH) have been intensely explored owing to their abundant reserves, low-cost, and tunable composition [16–18]. However, the poor conductivity and low charge transfer ability of NiFe LDH severely limit their widespread applications in electrocatalysis. Some researchers used FeNi-LDH as a semi-sacrificial template or an anion-induced method to optimize the NiFe LDH to further improve the OER kinetics [19]. However, there is still a major gap between the HER performance of the existing catalysts and Pt, despite the notably lower costs [20]. For instance, the price of Ru is only 1/3 of Pt, and Ru is a promising Pt substitute for electrocatalysis because of highly chemical resistance [21]. However, in various studies of Ru and Ru-based nanostructures, Ru nanoparticles are easy to agglomerate during the preparation of Ru-based nanomaterials [22]. Therefore, the use of appropriate supporting substrates can inhibit the aggregation of Ru nanoparticles, which is beneficial to the improvement of catalytic performance. Herein, we develop an in-situ approach for fabricating 0D/2D NiFe LDH-Ru hybrid as high-efficiency HER and OER catalysts by oil bath assisted heating to form Ru nanoparticles. The Ru nanoparticles doping can modify the local electronic structure of NiFe LDH and reduce the energy barrier for adsorption of water molecules. The results show that Ru incorporation enhanced the HER and OER by NiFe LDH catalysts by exposing a large number of and abundant highly-active sites. The prepared NiFe LDH-Ru catalyst can effectively drive HER and OER, while exhibiting the excellent electrocatalytic performance toward HER and OER with the low overpotentials of 52 and 217 mV to reach 10 mA cm−2, respectively, as well as the long-term stability. This work provides guidance for custom-designing high-performance electrocatalysts for diverse applications in clean energy and related fields. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and reagents The Iron nitrate nonahydrate Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)3·6H2O), and urea, RuCl3·xH2O and RuO2 were obtained from Aladdin Reagents Ltd. The KOH (AR, ≥ 85.0%) were purchased from Alfa. The commercial Pt/C (20 wt%) was purchased from Johnson Mattey Co./Ltd. All the reagents were used without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of the NiFe LDH/NF Typically, the Ni foam (NF, 1 × 1 cm−2) was cleaned with 1 M HCl, deionized water and ethanol. Thereafter, 10 mg Fe(NO3)3·9H2O, 100 mg Ni(NO3)3·6H2O, and 150 mg urea were mixed uniformly, and then the NF and the solution were transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave. The sealed reactor autoclave was heated at 120 °C for 12 h. Finally, the product was washed with deionized water (about 50 ml) and dried at 60 °C. 2.3 Synthesis of the NiFe LDH-Ru The prepared NiFe LDH/NF was immersed in 3 mg/mL RuCl3 solution and reacted at 60 °C for 12 h. The final product was washed with deionized water and ethyl alcohol (about 50 ml), respectively, and thus dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The obtained product was denoted as NiFe LDH-Ru. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements The HER and OER measurements were carried out using a three-electrode cell in a CHI660e workstation. The cell included the Ag/AgCl, carbon rod and the as-prepared products as the reference electrode, the counter electrode, whereas 1 M KOH solution was used as an electrolyte. The linear sweep voltammetry (LSV), electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) and chronopotentiometry curves were recorded by a conventional electrochemical workstation device. In addition, the CV curves with the scan rates from 20 to 100 mV s−1 were acquired to obtain the Cdl values. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) was assessed according to Cdl. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterizations of electrocatalyst The preparation route of NiFe LDH-Ru electrocatalyst is presented in Fig. 1a. Firstly, the NiFe LDH is synthesized by a hydrothermal method. Using RuCl3 as a Ru source, Ru loaded nanoparticles were grown evenly on NiFe LDH using the oil bath method to synthesize the NiFe LDH-Ru. As displayed in Fig. 1b, c, and d, the NiFe LDH-Ru with rough surfaces supports the nucleation of many Ru nanoparticles, and the Ru nanoparticles are uniformly loaded on the NiFe LDH surface. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) is performed to study the crystal structures of the products in Fig. S1 and Fig. S2, it can be observed that these peaks at 11.5°, 23.6°, 34.4°, 38.9°, 59.7° and 61.1°can be ascribed to (003), (006), (012), (015), (113) and (116) facets of FeNi-LDH (PDF#51–0463) [23], respectively. For NiFe LDH-Ru, the characteristic peak of the NiFe LDH-Ru has a positive shift compared to the NiFe LDH, indicating that ruthenium nanoparticles are successfully loaded the NiFe LDH-Ru surface. Besides, the XRD patterns of Ni LDH-Ru and Fe LDH-Ru do not show any significant peaks corresponding to ruthenium nanoparticles, thus indicating the small Ru loading. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) imaging further reveals the nanosheet structure of NiFe LDH-Ru shown in Fig. 1e. Additionally, the high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) micrograph exhibits the lattice fringe spacing of 0.23 and 0.214 nm shown in Fig. 1f, which corresponds to the (015) and (002) facets of NiFe LDH and Ru nanoparticles, respectively; this result is consistent with the previous report [24,25] and the SAED patterns in Fig. 1g. The energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping demonstrates a uniform distribution of Ni, Fe, O, and Ru elements throughout the NiFe LDH-Ru nanosheets, as seen in Fig. 1h. Furthermore, the composition and valence states of the NiFe LDH-Ru is analyzed by XPS characterization. The survey spectrum of the NiFe LDH-Ru is shown in Fig. S3, and reveals the existence of the Ni, Fe, O, and Ru. The content of the Ru is about 6.5% based on the XPS result, but Ru reveals apparent peaks confirming the Ru nanoparticles on the surface of NiFe LDH. As shown in Fig. 2a, the Fe 2p spectrum displays the peaks at 710.4 and 719.5 eV, and other two peaks at 704.3 and 735.6 eV are ascribed to Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 of Fe (III), respectively [26,27]. As for the Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 2b), the peaks at 852.9 and 870.6 eV are assigned to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively, which is accompanied by the peaks at 858.7 and 876.6 eV as the satellite peaks [28,29]. As revealed in Fig. 2c, the O 1 s spectra at 529.0 and 528.7 eV are in accordance with lattice oxygen and metal-O, respectively, which is consistent with the previously reported data [30]. The electronic state of the surface Ru species was further ascertained by the BE of Ru 3d in Fig. 2d, which presents the Ru 3d3/2 deconvoluted into three peaks based on the reported BEs with standard deviation [31]. The peaks with BE of 278.6 eV (Ru 3d5/2) and 285.9 eV (Ru 3d3/2) are ascribed to Ru0. The BE of Ru3+ are located at 282.0 eV (Ru 3d5/2). Furthermore, the N2 adsorption-desorption curves demonstrate that the specific surface area of the NiFe LDH-Ru is 24.3 m2 g−1 measured in Fig. S4, which is consistent with the isotherm of type III [32]. Better separation of the electrolyte from the catalyst surface into the interior is conducive to the rapid mass transport and electron transfer. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance for OER The electrocatalytic OER activity of the prepared NiFe LDH-Ru and other samples were studied by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) in 1 M KOH solution using a three-electrode system. As revealed in Fig. 3a and Fig. S5, the NiFe LDH-Ru exhibits a much lower overpotential compared to NiFe LDH, Fe LDH-Ru, Ni LDH-Ru and RuO2 samples, whereas the required overpotential of NiFe LDH-Ru to reach 10 mA cm−2 is only 217 mV in alkaline media, which is significantly lower than for, NiFe LDH (280 mV), Fe LDH-Ru (266 mV), Ni LDH-Ru (233 mV), RuO2 (256 mV), and its metal-based Ru (261 mV) in Fig. S6, as well as recently reported catalysts [33–36] and NiFe-based materials in Table S1. The Tafel slopes of NiFe LDH-Ru, Fe LDH-Ru, Ni LDH-Ru, and RuO2 are 63, 141, 103 and 85 mV dec−1, respectively (Fig. 3b). The small Tafel slopes of NiFe LDH-Ru indicate that the incorporation of Ru indeed can indeed promote the OER process. Long-term electrochemical stability is the next important parameter for practical applications. The NiFe LDH-Ru exhibits stable OER activity for 3000 cycles (Fig. 3c). Long-term stability is further evaluated by chronopotentiometry at 10 mA cm−2 for 24 h (the inset in Fig. 3c), which shows excellent electrochemical stability. In addition, the cyclic voltammetry curve of the Ni LDH-Ru and NiFe LDH-Ru are presented in Fig. 3d and Fig. 3e. The double layer capacitance (Cdl) measurements are performed to evaluate the electrochemical activity by CV, and there is a positive correlation between Cdl and CV. The Cdl value of NiFe LDH-Ru (9.9 mF cm2) is clearly larger than that of Ni LDH-Ru (7.9 mF cm2) in Fig. 3f, suggesting that NiFe LDH-Ru presents the higher values of ECSA for OER. This finding can be ascribed to the coexistence of Fe and Ni, which facilitates the OER activity. 3.3 Electrocatalytic performance for HER The HER performance of the NiFe LDH-Ru electrocatalyst is also assessed in a standard three-electrode device in the 1.0 M KOH solution. Fig. 4a and Fig. S7 reveals the linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) curves of the as-prepared electrodes, and the commercial Pt/C catalyst used as a reference sample. Compared to Fe LDH-Ru and Ni LDH-Ru samples, as well as its metal-based Ru in Fig. S8, the catalytic activity of NiFe LDH-Ru is notably higher. The overpotential of NiFe LDH-Ru (52 mV at −10 mA cm−2) is close to the commercial Pt/C (41 mV at −10 mA cm−2) and it exceeds the NiFe LDH (74 mV at −10 mA cm−2), Ni LDH-Ru (105 mV at −10 mA cm−2), Fe LDH-Ru (168 mV at −10 mA cm−2), as well as other recently reported catalysts [37–40], as well as Ru-based materials in Table S2. The Tafel slope of NiFe LDH-Ru is 108 mV dec−1, which is much lower than those of Ni LDH-Ru (155 mV dec−1), Fe LDH-Ru (197 mV dec−1), and close to the Pt/C (104 mV dec−1) samples, as shown in Fig. 4b. The decreased Tafel slope of the NiFe LDH-Ru implies the accelerated rate-limiting step, which is favorable for the HER kinetics. Furthermore, the LSV of the NiFe LDH-Ru exhibits a very stable HER activity after 3000 cycles (Fig. 4c). The long-term durability of the NiFe LDH-Ru is further evaluated by chronopotentiometry at 10 mA cm−2 for continuous operation of 24 h (Fig. 4d), which confirms its notable stability. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was used to further characterize the HER activity of NiFe LDH-Ru. The Nyquist curves in Fig. 4e yielded the charge transfer resistance (R ct) associated with electrocatalytic kinetics. This result reveals that the NiFe LDH-Ru has a much smaller R ct value than Ni LDH-Ru and Fe LDH-Ru samples, which suggests faster electron transfer and higher HER activity, which is consistent with the LSV measurements in Fig. 4a. In addition, the XRD data show that the structural changes after the electrochemical reaction are very small, which indicates that the catalyst is stable, see Fig. S9. As shown in Fig. S10, the XPS analysis is further carried after the electrochemical performance test. It can be observed that the Ni 2p and Fe 2p spectra are almost unchanged compared to the state before the reaction, and the Ru 3d spectrum changes obviously. Through the strong metal-substrate interaction between Ru and NiFe LDH substrate, the oxidation state fluctuation can be kept low during the electrocatalytic reaction. Moreover, the atomic Ru site can be stabilized, and the catalyst can avoid structural recombination. At the same time, Ru site can stabilize the Ni and Fe catalytic sites, so that the structural sites can avoid the chemical bonding and structural distortion caused by the oxidation of Ni and Fe sites during the electrochemical reaction. Therefore, the NiFe LDH-Ru catalyst really achieves a stable dual catalytic reaction site through a very strong metal-substrate interaction and is indeed an effective bi-functional electrocatalyst. Based on the bifunctional catalytic characteristic for HER and OER, two NiFe LDH-Ru electrodes were further applied to assemble a two-electrode electrolyzer (Fig. 5a). Importantly, the two-electrode device generates a lot of bubbles. As shown in Fig. 5b, the assembled electrolyzer output voltage is 1.59 at 10 mA cm−2 for the overall water splitting, which surpasses typical reported values in alkaline media. Besides, the long-term stability of NiFe LDH-Ru is measured at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. The catalyst can maintain the initial current density after 24 h of continuous reaction, confirming the excellent stability of NiFe LDH-Ru in overall water electrolysis confirmed by the results presented in Fig. 5c. The results prove that the Ru nanoparticles anchored on NiFe LDH can modulate the electronic structure of NiFe LDH-Ru, thus facilitating its intrinsic catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have developed a bifunctional electrocatalyst which demonstrated a notable activity for both HER and OER reactions in alkaline medium. The catalyst was synthesized by anchoring highly dispersed Ru nanoparticles on NiFe LDH. The NiFe LDH-Ru exhibits excellent catalytic activity, highlighted by an overpotential of 52 and 217 mV toward the HER and OER at 10 mA cm−2, respectively, which surpasses the reported performance of advanced NiFe-based catalysts. The NiFe LDH-Ru catalyst was further used as both a cathode and an anode in an overall water splitting cell. The assembled water electrolysis device also showed excellent electrocatalytic activity. The achieved electrocatalytic performance can be ascribed to strong interactions between Ru and NiFe LDH, prevented Ru migration and aggregation, collectively ensuring the demonstrated catalytic durability. The work opens a new avenue for the rational design and production of NiFe-based materials for clean and sustainable energy related applications that require high catalytic activity and stability. Yaozhen Qian: Data curation, Validation. Meng Wu: Visualization, Investigation. Shuyan Hu: Validation. Jingyuan Zhang: Validation. Xingwang Zhu: Supervision. Kostya (Ken) Ostrikov: Writing – review & editing. coredata.dc:description: Developing efficient and stable bifunctional electrocatalysts is highly desirable for boosting the energy efficiency of water splitting. Herein, we propose an effective ruthenium nanoparticle anchoring approach to reconstruct NiFe LDH including the customized morphology and configuration of active species. The synthesized NiFe LDH-Ru shows an excellent HER and OER performance with low overpotentials of 52 and 217 mV at 10 mA cm−2, respectively, which exceeds most of the existing HER and OER catalysts. Moreover, the NiFe LDH-Ru catalyst also presents excellent long-term stability. This work provides a new approach for exploring efficient electrocatalysts for clean and renewable energy applications.
coredata.prism:publisher: The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Highly stable Ru nanoparticles anchored on NiFe layered double hydroxides as efficient water splitting electrocatalysts
coredata.prism:copyright: © 2023 The Authors. Published by Elsevier B.V.
